beats.reasoning: Intro is low‑energy and builds tension; beat 1 is a downbeat but not a drop or lyrical highlight, so we leave breathing room to keep the start subtle and avoid over‑stimulation.

Low‑energy intro with a high‑band focus; to build tension gradually we leave this beat as breathing room, avoiding motion or VFX that would break the subtle atmosphere. According to the 60‑70% sync rule and intro guidelines, beat 2 is best left empty.

At 1% of the track, the intro is still building tension with low energy and no lyrics, so we keep the beat silent to provide breathing room and avoid over‑lighting early on. This follows the 60‑70% sync rule and the professional guideline to keep intro light subtle and minimal.

Beat 4/255 is in the very early intro, low energy, high‑band dominant. Following the 60‑70% sync rule and the intro guidelines, we provide breathing room and avoid any motion or VFX to build tension gradually.

Beat 5/255 falls in the very early intro, low energy, high‑band dominance and a calm mood. A subtle moving‑head wave provides breathing tension without overpowering the vocals, following the 60–70% sync rule and keeping VFX off until the drop.

Beat 6/255 falls in the intro where the energy is low and the sound is building tension; professional rules advise minimal lighting to keep the atmosphere subtle. Keeping this beat silent provides breathing room and follows the 60‑70% sync guideline for early intro beats.

Beat 7 falls in the intro where energy is low and the dominant band is high. According to professional rules, we introduce a subtle motion to build tension without overwhelming the vocals—using a single moving head with a gentle wave and a cool static color supports the early build while keeping the lighting restrained.

Beat 8/255 falls within the intro, a low‑energy, mid‑band dominated section where subtlety is key. Following professional rules, we keep this beat quiet to allow breathing room and gradual build‑up toward later phrases.

Beat 12 falls early in the intro where we want subtle build‑up. The medium high‑energy cue merits a gentle motion rather than strobe or VFX. A single rotating wash with a static cool color and mild intensity modulation supports vocals without overwhelming the calm start.

At beat 13 (~5% of the track) the intro is still building tension; energy is medium but dominant bass indicates a gentle build rather than a drop. To maintain a gradual and subtle feel, this beat receives breathing room with no effects, following the 60‑70% sync rule and the intro guidelines.

At ~5% of the track this is still intro territory, so we keep the lighting subtle and build‑tension. The beat has medium energy but no VFX or strobe; a single rotating light with a cool static color and gentle intensity wave adds motion without overpowering the early atmosphere.
